sub_topic: Solving systems of linear equations using Cramer's rule
message_1:
Solve the following system of linear equations using Cramer's rule:

2x + 3y - z = 6

4x - 2y + z = -1

x + 2y + 4z = 4
message_2:
To solve the given system of linear equations using Cramer's rule, we first need to find the determinant of the coefficient matrix, which we'll call D. The coefficient matrix is:

| 2  3 -1 |
| 4 -2  1 |
| 1  2  4 |

D = 2((-2)(4) - (1)(2)) - 3((4)(4) - (1)(1)) + (-1)((4)(2) - (-2)(1))
D = 2(-8 - 2) - 3(16 - 1) + (-1)(8 + 2)
D = 2(-10) - 3(15) + (-1)(10)
D = -20 - 45 - 10
D = -75

Now we need to find the determinants of the matrices obtained by replacing the columns of the coefficient matrix with the constant terms of the equations. We'll call these determinants Dx, Dy, and Dz.

For Dx, replace the first column with the constants (6, -1, 4):

| 6  3 -1 |
| -1 -2  1 |
| 4  2  4 |

Dx = 6((-2)(4) - (1)(2)) - 3((-1)(4) - (1)(4)) + (-1)((-1)(2) - (-2)(4))
Dx = 6(-8 - 2) - 3(-4 - 4) + (-1)(-2 + 8)
Dx = 6(-10) - 3(-8) + (-1)(6)
Dx = -60 + 24 - 6
Dx = -42

For Dy, replace the second column with the constants (6, -1, 4):

| 2  6 -1 |
| 4 -1  1 |
| 1  4  4 |

Dy = 2((-1)(4) - (1)(4)) - 6((4)(4) - (1)(1)) + (-1)((4)(4) - (1)(1))
Dy = 2(-4 - 4) - 6(16 - 1) + (-1)(16 - 1)
Dy = 2(-8) - 6(15) - 15
Dy = -16 - 90 - 15
Dy = -121

For Dz, replace the third column with the constants (6, -1, 4):

| 2  3  6 |
| 4 -2 -1 |
| 1  2  4 |

Dz = 2((-2)(4) - (-1)(2)) - 3((4)(4) - (-1)(1)) + 6((4)(2) - (-2)(1))
Dz = 2(-8 + 2) - 3(16 + 1) + 6(8 + 2)
Dz = 2(-6) - 3(17) + 6(10)
Dz = -12 - 51 + 60
Dz = -3

Now we can find the values of x, y, and z using the determinants:

x = Dx / D = -42 / -75 = 14 / 25
y = Dy / D = -121 / -75 = 121 / 75
z = Dz / D = -3 / -75 = 1 / 25

So, the solution to the given system of linear equations is:

x = 14/25
y = 121/75
z = 1/25
